top_comment.text:
I have been told to my face I am homely . I seriously hate how this culture 
judges me.﻿
top_comment.author: samdecat67

comments.text:
+Sarah M No I'm not Sarah M...nice try...but I don't need to have a degree 
in Psychology to regonize an asshole when I see one. :-)
comments.author: Crystal Coleman (Chosen1)

comments.text:
+Crystal Coleman Lol I had a great childhood but nice try. I wasn't aware 
that you were a psychologist but thanks for the advice and analyzing my 
life! :)
comments.author: Sarah M

comments.text:
+Sarah M Your insensitive remark shows you have some emotional abuse and 
judgement in your childhood too. Hurt people...hurt people. Seek help ; )
comments.author: Crystal Coleman (Chosen1)

comments.text:
+samdecat67
sorry, why did we just read your life story about your mom being terrible 
to you? There are some things you just don't need to share with a million 
strangers.
comments.author: Sarah M

comments.text:
+samdecat67 I have what the beauty industry calls droopy eyes(context). 
back when I was in highschool my mom and I took the same swimming lesson, 
after 2 hours of training, class ended, I took a hot shower and all that 
was in my mind was to head home and take a nap. My mom always used to yell 
at me that I had an annoying look on my face, that nobody would like to 
look at me in the eyes becuase I looked dull and boring and way too 
serious. She always complained to the other women in the changing room 
strangers that her daughter would end up alone because she could see, 
through my face, that there was no cheerfulness or generosity  in me...
comments.author: 0MissNemo0

comments.text:
Your mother was self hating and cruel. I am sorry she projected her pain 
onto you.
comments.author: callynt

comments.text:
to clarify the statement came from my mom, At age 5 shopping to clothes to 
go to kindergarten, she pronounced me fat. I was made to go to weight 
watchers by the 5th. grade. when my teen acne showed up she relentless 
ordered me to scrub my face. Around age 16 she acquired an Instamatic   
camera and any pictures she got of me would be accompanied with arrows 
pointing to my flaws.  She set the stage for me to marry 2 men who would 
replicate that message I am just not good enough. at 46 even with therapy I 
an not stand to see myself in a picture. I know it is her baggage loaded on 
to me, however I simply  still hear the nagging when I catch a glimpse of 
myself in a reflective surface. Your video was great and I wish there had 
been an internet years ago for me to have known it's mom, society and 
advertising that can't see where true beauty lies.
comments.author: samdecat67

comments.text:
Seriously? They must have been feeling that way about themselves & 
projecting their negative feelings onto you. In regards to this video, I 
think we can't ignore that men can feel this way too. I think all men have 
something to make them handsome, no matter what size or shape.
comments.author: Tanya Beatty

comments.text:
The person who said you looked homely must have some pretty serious issues 
of his/her own... so, ignore the way she /he lashes out, you have nothing 
to do with it. Don't believe that person for a second.
comments.author: Iggypox

top_comment.text:
i'm a trans woman, i don't pass as female for the majority of time.. for 
the majority of my life i have been unsafe, at risk of attack and 
harrasment and personal shame, all because of my appearance. it's going to 
cost me £19000 to give me a footing in society, i just wish other women new 
how incredibly lucky and beautiful they are.﻿
top_comment.author: alexa olsen

comments.text:
I wish I was as sure of who I am as you are sure of who you are.  Much 
love, sister.  <3
comments.author: Laura Burgett

comments.text: +alexa olsen Anna is probably a weaboo troll.
comments.author: Yvonne de Rooij

comments.text:
+Anna Nakamoto  hahaha i don't want to be a woman - i was born a woman. 
you're clearly uneducated on the subject and have a belief system based on 
fear - plus you're sentiment speaks volumes about your character "you 
aren't accepting". please keep your "sins" to yourself, because it's 
ignorant folks like you that can end up destroying the quality of life for 
some of the most vulnerable groups in society, just so you can feel self 
righteous - and i'm sure you don't intend on harming others :)
comments.author: alexa olsen

comments.text:
+alexaolsen why do you want to be a women? You aren't accepting. Accept 
yourself for who you are. A man. You can turn from your sins. Being 
transsexual is a sin. Jesus wants you to turn away from that. You can be 
amazing through Christ.
comments.author: Anna Nakamoto

comments.text:
+Elga John 
It is for myself, to make my life more bearable.
I would never change my appearance just to please another.
I am not of the weak willed, low self esteem kind. I am a realist.
I have no illusions that people will stop finding something wrong with me 
if they look for it. I will not be perfect because nobody is.
I could take offense in a person who assumes I am so weak as to do it for 
others and so stupid that I have not given it ample thought.
Although it tires me a little, I choose not to take offense because your 
assumption says more about you and the state of western society than it 
says about me.
Nor do I have to write back to you or explain myself, but in the spirit of 
civility and education I just have.
I am curious as to what god or other deity you prayed to, but since 
religious matters are so very delicate I risk offending you.
comments.author: Yvonne de Rooij

comments.text:
+Yvonne de Rooij
I don't know if I can stop you from doing what you want to do.. But first 
think for yourself for whom are doing this, is for for yourself or for 
others? If its for others then this world is never going to stop finding 
fault with you. My prayers are with you.
comments.author: Elga John

comments.text: You sound like an amazing woman :)
comments.author: Nichole Sinclair

comments.text:
It's horrible that we, if we don't conform to labels, are at risk of attack 
and harassment the moment we step out the door. However that's the nature 
of our world, so believe me when I say that those 16000 pounds are well 
spent.
I'll be spending around 10000 euro's for a similar reason, just because I 
am not safe outside.
I'm not transgender or transsexual, I have down-syndrome markers on my face 
even when I don't have down-syndrome.
It's just bad luck I was born with this face.
I've had people throw garbage at me, shout abuse, beat me up and just 
generally harass me in the street.
Strangers who mean well treat me like a child, people with actual down 
syndrome think I'm one of them and believe me when I say that if you look 
the way I look you are not considered part of society or even as a 
potential date.
I'll always be outside of society, no matter what job I get, no matter 
which clothes I wear, no matter what kind of make-up I wear and no matter 
how I style my hair.
They just make me look like a down syndrome person with nice clothes and 
hair.
I have no hope of passing as a normal human being (in other peoples eyes).
At least until I get my facial bones ground down and reshaped by a surgeon.
I hope it will be enough because they can't reposition the eyes.
comments.author: Yvonne de Rooij

comments.text:
You know who you are. Don't let bullies dictate your self worth or your 
beauty! I've been around several trans women. The most salient thing is 
actually not their feminine or masculine features, but their level of 
confidence with themselves! Please trust a complete stranger when I say 
that confidence is beautiful! :)
comments.author: Kira Catherine

comments.text:
:( I wished we were at a point in our culture we wouldn't let a person 
express and be whoever they want to be, without feeling unsafe and at 
danger.
comments.author: Yua ToA

top_comment.text:
All of this is bullshit. I'm ugly no matter how much makeup I put on or 
what I do with my makeup. I could be wearing the most expensive dress in 
the world, tailored to fit my figure perfectly, and I'd still be 
loathsomely ugly. She has it so much easier than people like me. ﻿
top_comment.author: Εφήμερα

comments.text:
I don't know you and can't know your situation, but I'm sorry about all the 
pain you've gone through. The point of this video, I think, is that almost 
every woman feels worse about herself than she should. Surely you have many 
amazing qualities, even if you are not going to be recognized as a great 
beauty (like most of us are not). I don't know what else to say other than 
that people who criticize others for their looks are jerks. Maybe someday 
you can lay aside the pain that it's caused you and focus on other things 
in life. There will always be jerks, but they don't have to control 
everything you do with your life.
comments.author: generationutena

comments.text:
Haha I thought the same. Make-up or clothings can't heal my face and body. 
So I use photoshop. :D I love it because it's a form of art. But in real 
life there is no photoshop and people will tell you all the time how ugly 
you are. How fat, how uneven your face, how less hair you have on your 
head... So this nice lady can talk how long as she wants to. It's nice to 
try to cheer people up. But if you are real ugly this will not help. People 
won't stop to hate you and calling you names because you just watched this 
video. :'D
comments.author: TilskKarishma

comments.text:
+Tanya Beatty Maybe this was because everyone show her hate. If you be 
treated your whole life like shit because you look ugly you become this. 
Believe me...
comments.author: TilskKarishma

comments.text:
I once knew a girl who could've been called ugly by society standards. But 
I always see something beautiful in people, so I could see she had very 
beautiful eyes. But what made her hideous to me was how mean & evil she 
would behave. I couldn't be her friend because of her terrible inside. And 
that made her ugly, and her eyes no longer seemed pretty.
comments.author: Tanya Beatty

comments.text: If that's what you believe, then that's what you'll see.  :(
comments.author: Letters from a Psychopath

comments.text:
+Letters from a Psychopath unforchently people in society these days don't 
look at personality anymore if they don't like the outside then they won't 
give any second thought too get to know the inside.
comments.author: Jess Louise

comments.text:
Are you ugly on the inside?  Cause who fuckin cares about the rest. People 
will see you exactly how you see yourself (truly)... took me a long time to 
learn that.
comments.author: Letters from a Psychopath

comments.text: You missed the entire point.
comments.author: The48cats

top_comment.text: Well, to be fair, if I looked like her, I wouldn't complain either!﻿

comments.text:

not to dismiss other people based on that.
comments.author: ELWest1000

+ELWest1000 sorry hard to tell on post sometimes. Let's agree you and me

comments.text:
+Lynn Ford I was being sarcastic--I don't see this self-loathing changing 
any time soon, at least not until we stop judging everyone on what they 
look like.
comments.author: ELWest1000

comments.text: please watch the video again, you ,missed the whole point

top_comment.text: i almost cried (but im not done yet)﻿
top_comment.author: Alexandra Defreitas

comments.text:
Lmao I thought I was the only one who cried but I realise a lot of us do as 
well.
comments.author: Noppi Neko

comments.text:
As cheesy as it sounds I shed tears there. I'm not always buying the 
"you're beautiful just the way you are" motto all the time because I've 
never felt the sincerity behind the speech. That talk finally made me feel 
that so... Thank you Eva !
comments.author: David Bourgeois

captions.text: "I'm sorry you have to touch my face.
Look at this breakout; I look disgusting."
"I'm sorry, but I am not a pretty woman."

"No. Thank you, but no.
I look like crap."

"The doctor says
that I have to lose weight.

So, sorry. This is what
you gotta work with."

"I look in the mirror, and
all I see is a tired mom.

And I see these wrinkles,
and I feel old and ugly."

And this is what I hear every single
solitary day of my life.

I am a makeup artist,
and these are real words from real women.

I'm also an actress,
but for my past 7 years of doing makeup,
I have discovered,

within the first 3 seconds
of sitting in my chair,

almost every single woman apologizes
to me for the way she looks.
Doesn't matter how young, how old,

what socioeconomic background
she comes from,
how traditionally beautiful she is,

almost every single woman apologizes
and does not feel that she measures up
to this new standard of beauty.

And I'm sure that maybe some of you
might be able to relate
to this apology thing?
I see some of you nodding.
Well, it just so happens

that I was actually the makeup artist
for TEDx last year,

and the same thing happened
when these incredibly innovative women
sat in my chair.
They apologized.

Now, I have discovered that
there is a very small group of women
who don't apologize.

And these are the movers, the shakers,
they're the powerhouses.
They could be CEO's, or stay-at-home moms,

but they don't measure themselves
by a mirror.

Sure, they wear makeup,
but they don't apologize for it.
They live in the moment,

and they let themselves have
that pleasure of living in the moment
and in the now.
And I am in awe of these women.

And there's probably some of you
very rare, precious, confident creatures
in this audience.

And to you ladies, I say go ahead
and take a bathroom break!

You can be back in like 5½ minutes
or something, because you don't need this!
You don't need to hear what I have to say.

And the other women
in this very small group

are the women who are aware
of their own mortality.
And I'll get back to them in a little bit.

So, a woman will make
an appointment with me
for a variety of different reasons.

A lot of times, she just feels down
about the way she looks,

and her friend will tell her, "Oh,
you have to go see Eva, she's amazing.

She's great. She'll teach you
makeup tricks,
it's going to change your life."
But I have to be honest.

I think that makeup
is the very least of what I do.
But I'm not saying, denying,
that makeup does not play a very real part

in making a woman feel more attractive,
and thus more confident,
because we're all aware

of those biological cues
of attraction between human beings,
like symmetry, and color, and light.

And when we see them in ourselves
or somebody else,
it pleases our primordial senses.

And I, as a makeup artist,
am very adept with the skills and tools

to very easily manipulate and enhance
those bio-cues on the face.
That's my job.
But I'll be honest with you.

I think every single woman
who sits in my chair
is beautiful with or without makeup.
She just has no idea!
Which is why I like to think of myself

as treading in the deep end
of a shallow profession.
(Laughter)

Because I use makeup as my tool
to help her believe it.
Makeup is my therapy puppet

to help a woman open up
about how she's feeling,

and express to me what her concerns are,
so I can address them.

And you know what?
It works!

Almost every time, I see
a woman leap up out of my chair
with this new skip in her step.

I see her actually look in the mirror
and actually smile at herself,
even if it's temporary.

There is a very real transformation
that happens in this chair.

"Oh no. What are you talking about?
I am not a pretty woman.

My mother-in-law says that
I have a round face,

and there is no way to make
a round, fat face pretty."

And I can't believe what I hear,
because all I see is a beautiful woman.

And I say, "Matir, but look at your
gorgeous, golden skin!

Here, hold the mirror,
watch what I'm doing.
Look at these perfect almond eyes,

these lips, my God,
in my next life, I want these lips.
Your smile just lit up this room!"
"You're right."

Now, you would think
because this is my job,

and I do this everyday,
and I hear what women say,
and I have this unique perspective,
that I would be different.

But -- here's what happens
when I sit in somebody's makeup chair.

"Oh, God. I'm sorry,
I have a very tough face.

I hate that I am actually dependent
on eyeliner
to even walk out my front door.

Oh, oh no, don't worry,
my nose is like a Muppet's fist.
Just like ee, ee, erh.
So, no worries trying to cover it up."

I have said those exact words
in somebody else's makeup chair!
I, too, do not feel that I measure up,

or can hold up to this insane,
new measure of beauty in this world,

that's like porn and fashion,
and Photoshop, all mixed up in one.

(Laughter)
(Applause)
Yeah. Good luck with that.
(Applause)

And it's not going away.
So what are we going to do?

What am I going to do
to feel and appreciate what I have?

Which brings me back to that other
small group of women
that don't apologize.
Oh -- all right -- ah
"It's my birthday!

I'm 96 years old,
and I'm on borrowed time now, honey.
But, I think I look pretty good."

"Ah, this feels so good,
I'm going to fall asleep.

Yes, I have two little ones.
Two and four year old.

And I just had a double mastectomy,
and six rounds of chemo.

So, I'm just so happy
to be pampering myself.
And I have to say, I love my new wig!"
Is this what it's going to take for me?

Is this what it's going to take
for me to appreciate what I have?

To be confronted with the prospect
of illness or death?

Is that what it's going to take for us
to appreciate what we have?
Well, I'm not going to take that.
I don't accept it.

So, in desperate need
for a solution to all of this,
I thought, "What can I do?"

So, I thought, "Well, why don't I do
what other women do?

They do it, and it works for them,
even if it's temporary.
Why don't I try it?
Why don't I sit in Eva's chair?"

"What would Eva say to me
if I apologized to Eva?"
I know. It sounds cheesy. I know.
But it's actually very scary.

It's the reason why I didn't even want
to finish this TED talk to begin with.
Because it's what I know I need to do.
Eva, stop saying that about your eyes.
You have your mother's eyes,
and you would never think for a second

that this woman who gave you life
and wisdom was not measuring up.

Okay, stop.
Eva, stop saying that about your nose.

You have your father's
and grandmama's nose.
Yes, your Italian genes are prominent,
but so is your spirit because of it!

And you can identify the notes
of a lush, jammy Primitivo wine
better than most because of it, probably.
So, I guess I'm deciding

that if lining my eyes brings symmetry
to my face and to my mind,
then I guess I'll do it.
And if adding a touch of color to my lips

allows me to bring joy and color
to my speech --
then why the heck not?

And if adding light reflection to my skin
gives me the little boost of confidence

for me to shed light on a
seemingly superficial topic
to a group of intellectuals,
then I will do it!
And that makes me feel beautiful.

And I will sit in my chair,
and I will listen, and believe,
that we are all beautiful.
I will make that appointment.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: In my chair -- a makeup artists perspective on beauty: Eva DeVirgilis at TEDxRVAWomen
